articles.title: Segment 1: The Basics of ggplot2
articles.contents:
Contents
R Markdown
Including Plots

R Markdown
This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.
When you click the Knit button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:


summary(cars)


     speed           dist       
 Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
 1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
 Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
 Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
 3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
 Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00  

Including Plots
You can also embed plots, for example:



Note that the echo = FALSE parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.

articles.title: Dr Cédric Scherer
articles.contents:
Hands-On DataViz with ggplot2
          
          
          Schedule
          
          
          Slides
           
          ▾
          
          
          1. The Grammar of Graphics
          2. Build Plots Layer by Layer
          3. Polish Your Visualization
          4. Provide Context with Annotations
          5. Create Multi-Panel Figures 
          
          
          
          
          Notebooks
           
          ▾
          
          
          1. The Grammar of Graphics
          2. Build Plots Layer by Layer
          3. Polish Your Visualization
          4. Provide Context with Annotations
          5. Create Multi-Panel Figures 
          
          
          
          
          Codes
           
          ▾
          
          
          1. The Grammar of Graphics
          2. Build Plots Layer by Layer
          3. Polish Your Visualization
          4. Provide Context with Annotations
          5. Create Multi-Panel Figures 
          
          
          About
          
          
          
          
          
          
          ☰
          
          
      
        
          
            
              
            
              Dr Cédric Scherer
            
            
              
                
                    
                      
                        Homepage
                      
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      
                        Twitter
                      
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      
                        LinkedIn
                      
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      
                        GitHub
                      
                    
                  
                                  
            
          
        
        
        
          
            Cédric is a graduated computational ecologist with a passion for design. In 2020, he combined his expertise in analyzing and visualizing large data sets in R with his passion to become a freelance data visualization specialist.
            Cédric has created visualizations across all disciplines, purposes, and styles and regularly teaches data visualization principles, R, and ggplot2. Due to regular participation to social data challenges, he is now well known for complex and visually appealing figures, entirely made with ggplot2, that look as they have been created with a vector design tool.
          
        
      
    

    
      
        
          
            
              
            
              Dr Cédric Scherer
            
            
              
                
                                    
                    
                      Homepage
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      Twitter
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      LinkedIn
                    
                  
                                    
                    
                      GitHub
                    
                  
                                  
              
            
            
              Cédric is a graduated computational ecologist with a passion for design. In 2020, he combined his expertise in analyzing and visualizing large data sets in R with his passion to become a freelance data visualization specialist.
              Cédric has created visualizations across all disciplines, purposes, and styles and regularly teaches data visualization principles, R, and ggplot2. Due to regular participation to social data challenges, he is now well known for complex and visually appealing figures, entirely made with ggplot2, that look as they have been created with a vector design tool.

articles.title: Hands–On Data Visualization with ggplot2
articles.description: How to Create Engaging and Well–Designed Visualizations in R
articles.contents:
Overview
This is the home page for the Pearson–O’Reilly Live Training Session “Hands–On Data Visualization with ggplot2”. All course materials will be posted on this site.
Details
Instructor: Dr Cédric SchererDate: September 3, 2021
What You’ll Learn
Load data into R and visualize it with the help of the powerful ggplot2 library.
Customize your ggplot2 output as you like including theming, colors, annotations, and many more.
Get to know useful extension libraries that will boost your workflow and improve your ggplot2 design.
Use Rmarkdown notebooks to build reproducible reports.
Get insights how to prepare and wrangle data with the popular tidyverse package collection.
Who is the Training for
Anyone interested in creating visually appealing charts with R and ggplot2—no matter if you have no or minimal experience with R.
Data scientists aiming to use the powerful ggplot2 library in their workflow for exploration and communication.
Business managers that aim to quickly gain data insights based on reproducible and elegantly formatted charts and reports.
Prerequisites and Preparation
Familiarity with Rstudio (required)Suggested Material:
Book: Chapter 1 of “R for Data Science” by Hadley Wickham & Garrett Grolemund
Video: Chapter 2 of “R Programming for Statistics and Data Science” by 365 Careers

Basic Knowledge of R (helpful but not required)Suggested Material:
Book: Chapter 4–6 of “R for Data Science” by Hadley Wickham & Garrett Grolemund
Book: Chapter 1–3 “R for Everyone: Advanced Analytics and Graphics, 2nd Edition” by Jared Lander
Book: Section 1 and 3 “Programming Skills for Data Science: Start Writing Code to Wrangle, Analyze, and Visualize Data with R” by Joel Ross & Michael Freeman
Video: Chapters 3, 4, and 7 of “R Programming for Statistics and Data Science” by 365 Careers

Data Wrangling with the tidyverse (helpful but not required)Suggested Material:
Book: Chapter 9–16 (Section: Wrangle) of “R for Data Science” by Hadley Wickham & Garrett Grolemund
Scenario: “Format and Shape Your Data in R with the Tidyverse” by Martin Frigaard

Course Set-Up
To run any of the materials locally on your own machine, you will need the following:
A recent version of R (download from here) and RStudio, (download from here).
for more detailed instructions see Chapter 2 of “R Programming for Statistics and Data Science” by 365 Careers

The following R packages: tidyverse (includes ggplot2), ggrepel, ggtext, patchwork, ggforce, ragg, magick.
You can install all required R packages at once by running the following code in the R command line:


# Package names
packages <- c("tidyverse", "ggrepel", "ggtext", "patchwork", "ragg", "magick")
install.packages(packages)



Reuse
Text and figures are licensed under Creative Commons Attribution CC BY 4.0.Note that figures in slides may be pulled in from external sources and may be licensed under different terms.

articles.title: Course Schedule
articles.description: The live video training session takes 5 hours and constists of five segments. Each segment contains a lecture, hands-on examples, exercises, and a Q&A session.
articles.contents:

Duration: 60 min
Motivation: The ggplot2 Showcase

Combine Multiple Plots with patchwork
